body: [This link](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/HEAD@%7B2017-06-30T21:58:22Z%7D/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/StringDimensionIndexer.java#L215) works for me. No, that was fixed in #5278.
Opened now to get any comments on approach before finishing enumerating the different metrics
Thanks for figuring that out. I just reproed using your exact example.

>> with 0 requiredCapacity overlord would try and send them to MM but MM would reject them saying its full, no ?

> Hmm, I just tested with RemoteTaskRunner and it worked. Is MM supposed to reject it?

looked at the code and workers just do whatever overlord tells them, so behavior you saw is expected and required to fulfill the contract of `requiredCapacity = 0`. however, that means overlord would just keep assigning supervisor tasks to MMs as they come . Even if `requiredCapacity = 0`, in reality they do take resources on the MM and would eventually kill it if enough number of those show up.
Opened now to get any comments on approach before finishing enumerating the different metrics

@jihoonson I am thinking of adding a tuning config in `ParallelIndexTuningConfig` , `minSplitsForParallelMode` . `ParallelIndexSupervisorTask` would run parallel only if `firehoseFactory.getNumSplits() >= minSplitsForParallelMode` or else it will run sequentially.

default value of `minSplitsForParallelMode=0` to retain existing behavior .

in my case, I would set `minSplitsForParallelMode=2`. most tasks have `numSplits = 1` so they will just run sequentially and only few of them would really run parallel with subtasks , that would reduce the likelihood of deadlock. also it is probably more efficient to not go parallel if there is just 1 split.

what do you think ?

nevermind, I tried above and it didn't help my case as contrary to my thinking, most tasks had 2 splits.

running the supervisors on separate set of workers using #7066 is the only decent thing to do for now.
@HeIsRicky your problem is in selected charset. urf8mb4 is advised option nowadays for mysql but it breaks columns sizing in some apps. You can use `utf8_general_ci` instead.

@himanshug thank you for raising a proposal!

> Add a method `boolean Task.isSupervisor()` to `Task` interface which returns true if the task is a supervisor task that spawns subtasks to delegate work. `ParallelIndexSupervisorTask` would return `true` while all other current task impls would return `false`.

`ParallelIndexSupervisorTask` can has two different modes, i.e., sequential and parallel modes. If it runs in the sequential mode, the supervisor task will behave just like the `index` task and process all data by itself. I guess you can call `isParallelMode()` to check this.

> Add a `druid.worker.supervisorCapacity` configuration on middleManagers, which designates available slots to run supervisor tasks. This config is similar to `druid.worker.capacity` which designates available non-supervisor task slots.

Wondering if we can add an overlord configuration instead of middleManager one, like `druid.indexer.supervisorCapacityRatio` or `druid.indexer.supervisorMaxCapacity`, which automatically reserve the number of task slots for supervisor tasks out of the total task capacity reported by middleManagers. One advantage of this way is people can configure only overlords instead of middleManagers which are supposed to be more than overlords in the cluster. Or do you want a sort of special middleManager where every supervisor task runs on it?

`getLocations()` is called per segment, and the iterator returned from that method will be iterated to find a storage location where the segment can be stored. IMO, it's ok for these iterations to be separate as in `LeastBytesUsedStorageLocationSelectorStrategy`. The iterator will be iterated only when some storage locations have some problem and not be iterated in the normal case.
@ccaominh thank you for the review! Addressed most of them and left some questions.
@mohammadjkhan : Any updates here ? were you able to look into final review comments ?
did anyone ever figure this out?

@jihoonson thanks

>  I guess you can call isParallelMode() to check this.

Yes `ParallelIndexSupervisorTask.isSupervisor()` impl would be `return isParallelMode()` or something very close.

Both type of configurations have their merits I think. You already listed the advantages for overlord only configuration.
I was thinking `druid.worker.supervisorCapacity` for following reasons.
- this is my primary reason: supervisor tasks generally consume way less cpu/memory than the subtasks , so a worker can offer more of those slots.
- this allows segregating supervisor tasks to a dedicated pool of MMs if needed, this is secondary for me and I am not planning to really use this advantage.

one slight concern(may not really happen) is about race conditions with overlord config where it computed a number for available supervisor capacity, but then couple of worker disappeared and overlord used the old number for available supervisor capacity.

It is also possible to support both kind of configurations, this is not  a one-or-the-other situation really. Only disadvantage I see is that users will have more options and hence need more mental bandwidth to tune things.

what do you think?
This issue has been closed due to lack of activity. If you think that is incorrect, or the issue requires additional review, you can revive the issue at any time.

> It is also possible to support both kind of configurations, this is not a one-or-the-other situation really. Only disadvantage I see is that users will have more options and hence need more mental bandwidth to tune things.

I think it makes sense for a short term solution. In the long run, we need a better task scheduler. Maybe makes sense to add something similar to #6993.

LGTM

Can we update the documentation to make the intent clearer for `jvm/gc/cpu`?

jvm/gc/cpu | Cpu time in Nanoseconds spent on garbage collection. | gcName, gcGen | Sum of jvm/gc/cpu should be within 10-30% of sum of jvm/cpu/total, depending on the GC algorithm used (reported by JvmCpuMonitor)
-- | -- | -- | --

"Cpu time in Nanoseconds" sounds like a Timer to me.  Maybe something like "Count of Cpu time in Nanoseconds spent on garbage collection"

Keep surveying, but it could be the root cause

@jon-wei @asdf2014 @nishantmonu51 fixed spellcheck and LGTM alerts. All requested changes/updates are now complete. Thank you.

> I suppose AutoScaler can provision only one type of workers still?

That make sense to me. I think realtime tasks can require a cluster with not the same configuration as for batch ones. So probably overlord could accept an array of worker config specs via dynamic configuration API call.
I looked into the code and found that current ProvisioningStrategy implementations could be changed to select available Autoscaler from DefaultWorkerBehaviorConfig (it also should be changed to support multi-autoscalers declaration).
I could contribute such changes to code if it makes sense for everybody.

Uh, actually, upon further investigation, I noticed some custom changes made to `org.apache.druid.timeline.VersionedIntervalTimeline`. I did not realize they were there when raising this issue. I will verify if this issue reproduces on upstream druid and report back here.

Yes, there were some bugs in previous versions of quantiles aggregator. I
don't have a list of GitHub issues and pull requests, and it is a bit
difficult now to point out exactly what versions had what bug. For
instance, https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/7320
Unfortunately, when quantiles sketch was fixed, a bug in Theta sketch was
introduced. So I would recommend upgrading to the latest version of Druid
(0.16.0-incubating).

I'll also add that if the default is change in the future, this makes
refactoring easier. I think we should use constants instead of literal
values generally because they make refactoring easier and make it easier to
understand why a particular value is used.

Similar issue, but not in a subquery context just in a list of values:

Works:
```
SELECT 
	COUNT(*) AS "orders.count"
FROM druid.orders  AS orders

WHERE 
	orders.id in (1, 3, 5, 6, 7, 10, 12, 14, 15)  
LIMIT 20
```

```
SELECT 
	COUNT(*) AS "orders.count"
FROM druid.orders  AS orders

WHERE 
	NOT COALESCE(orders.id in (1, 3, 5, 6, 7, 10, 12, 14, 15)  , FALSE)
LIMIT 20
```

Throws:

```
Error -1 (00000) : Error while executing SQL "-- Looker Query Context '{"user_id":866,"history_id":5907381,"instance_slug":"b6ff28049851f1954156526c66ca9912"}' SELECT COUNT(*) AS "orders.count" FROM druid.orders AS orders WHERE NOT COALESCE(orders.id in (1, 3, 5, 6, 7, 10, 12, 14, 15) , FALSE) LIMIT 20": Remote driver error: ClassCastException: org.apache.calcite.sql.fun.SqlCase cannot be cast to org.apache.calcite.sql.SqlBasicCall
```

Hi @mitchlloyd, thanks for the contribution! 

It looks like this just passes through to the instance profile credentials, so it might be ok to not have to update any documentation since this is already mentioned in the [s3 aws authentication documentation](http://druid.apache.org/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/s3.html#s3-authentication-methods). I think [that doc](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/master/docs/development/extensions-core/s3.md) would probably be the place to update though if you feel we should elaborate or if any of the details from the [EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper docs](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/auth/EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper.html) seem useful to include in our documentation.

I also changed `dataSegment` to remember `lastCompactionState` including `partitionsSpec` and `indexSpec` per discussion at https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/8489#issuecomment-535794960.

I would definitely suggest updating the s3.md doc. There should be a new entry added between "Profile information" and "Instance profile information". The description could be something like,

> **Type:** EC2 container credentials
> **Details:** Based on environment variables `AWS_CONTAINER_CREDENTIALS_RELATIVE_URI` or `AWS_CONTAINER_CREDENTIALS_FULL_URI` as described in the [EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/auth/EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper.html).

I don't think tests are needed for this patch; they would be nice, but we don't currently have a good way to test the provider chain, and this patch doesn't need to be the place to add that testing ability.

I am good to merge this patch after the doc update I mentioned above. Thanks for the contribution @mitchlloyd!

Hi @teeram thank you for the report. I'm trying to replicate this error in my local but there has been no luck so far. Would you please answer to a couple of questions?

- Do you always see this error if you follow the steps in the issue?
- By any chance, did you update `druid_pendingSegments` or `druid_segments` table between the step 2 and 4 except dropping segments in some time chunks?

I updated the documentation in s3.md doc. Note that I changed the suggested wording slightly. It seems that `EC2ContainerCredentials` is a misleading name. The JavaScript SDK has a better name for this: [ECSCredentials](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaScriptSDK/latest/AWS/ECSCredentials.html). Really this is all about using ECS and this authentication method should work with ECS configured with EC2 instances and ECS configured with Fargate instances. 

With that in mind [I made sure to mention ECS](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/8651/commits/752cd6df3d71e0d7f1675b628969354d8d911940).

Next up, I'm going to test this change on an ECS cluster.
